titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Anna and Stanley Wilson Papers
titlestmt.author: Martha Lund Smalley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Monday March 25, 2019 at 22:27

did.unittitle: Anna and Stanley Wilson Papers
did.abstract: This collection documents the life and work of Anna Lane Wilson and Stanley Wilson, who were missionaries in China from 1917 to 1949, primarily serving at Yenching University. Of particular note are Anna Wilson's letters to family in the United States and journals document her voyage to China, missionary life, Chinese customs and celebrations, dress, architecture, the flu epidemic, climate, and political events.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ownership and copyright have been transferred to Yale University.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Anna and Stanley Wilson Papers (RG 220), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Anna Marie Lane Wilson (1892-1981) served as a missionary to China under the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions from 1919 to 1949. Leaving for China in September 1918, she taught Biology, Chemistry and other subjects at the North China Union Woman's College for five years and then, in 1923, married Stanley Davis Wilson.

Stanley Wilson(1881-1970) was professor of Chemistry at the Peking Union Medical College (supported by the Rockefeller Foundation). Shortly later, the Wilsons moved to the newly formed Yenching University outside Peking, where they lived and worked until interrupted by World War II in 1941. They were on furlough in the United States in 1924-1925. Stanley Wilson did not go to China as a missionary, but after he married Anna Lane and began his work at Yenching University, he was supported by the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions. In accordance with the custom at the time, Anna Lane no longer taught at the University following her marriage. Stanley Wilson was interned by the Japanese and repatriated half way through the war in a prisoner exchange. After the war the Wilsons returned to Yenching where they worked for another three years and were there during the takeover by the Communist regime, finally returning to California and retirement in 1949.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I - V of this collection primarily document the life and work of Anna Lane Wilson in China from 1918-1923. Detailed letters to family in the United States document her voyage to China, missionary life, Chinese customs and celebrations, dress, architecture, the flu epidemic, climate and relations/conflicts between Japan and China. Most of the letters are from before Anna's marriage to Stanley Wilson in 1923 and the subsequent births of their daughters Helen and Marian. Many of the letters in the collection have been transcribed by Anna Lane Wilson's daughter Helen Wilson Saunders. The transcriptions are available in printed form, filed with the originals, and also on a CD.

In addition to family correspondence, there is a small amount of general correspondence primarily to/from Stanley Wilson. Journals of Anna Lane Wilson from 1918-1919 and 1923 describe her voyage to China, her first year of work and a return trip to the United States. Collected material primarily relates to Peking University, later known as Yenching University.
Photographs in Series V include documentation of North China Union Woman's College, Yenching University, Peking Union Medical College and the Beijing area.

Series VI, Addendum, represents papers of Anna and Stanley Wilson that had been donated to the Library at an earlier times and were previously included in Record Group 8, China Records Project Miscellaneous Personal Papers. The correspondence in Series VI is primarily from a later period and documents Stanley Wilson's period of separation from his family during the Sino-Japanese war, including his internment by the Japanese. Also included are scientific writings of Wilson and documentation relating to Yenching University at the time of the Communist takeover in 1948-1949.

Additional documentation related to the work of Stanley and Anna Wilson at Yenching University is located in YDSL Record Group No. 11, Archives of the United Board for Christian Higher Education in Asia.

did.unittitle: Family correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These letters are from Anna Lane Wilson to her family in the U.S. A CD containing electronic copies of transcriptions of many of them is in the first folder.

did.unittitle: Incl. re. Preparations for voyage from Vancouver to China
Incl. re. Seasickness; crossing international date line; war in Egypt
Incl. at Kobe, Japan

Incl. re. arrival at North China Women's College in Peking, Learning Chinese; Red Cross knitting for Siberia; cultural differences (beauty, dress, binding of feet); conditions in Russia and Balkans; Spanish influenza; Temple of Heaven; Summer Palace; celebration of founding of Republic.
Incl. re. Chinese troops celebrating victory in Forbidden City; expectations of Chinese girls 12-16 yrs.
Incl. re. Christmas celebrations; rumors from Vladivostok Czechs killed; menus for meals; boys doing housekeeping; church entertainments.
Incl. re. Flu epidemic; Chinese money; funeral and wedding customs; calligraphy; 70,000 people in Peking destitute - beggars; China shortage of wood
Incl. re. Chinese New Year; entertaining; New Year customs; city and shops; concerns about Peace Conference – relations between China/Japan; foot binding custom
Incl. re. Chinese foreign relations – North/South; Japanese threat; life of English/American; servants; Korea (freedom from Japanese rule); visit to tombs of Manchu Emperors
Incl. re. Chinese schools - government higher normal school – men; Rockefeller Premedical School; life in Peking

Incl. re. Visit to Tsing Hua School (Indemnity College); camphor wood box; Japan takes Shantung; student march to Ts'ao Yulin home ("traitor"); role of League of Nations ("agent that insures Japan the fruits of her villainy"); Dr. Dickinson study of medical situation in China

Incl. re. Korea travel ill advised; sand fly infestation; student movement; college for women; women protest; possibility of revelution – student strikes, marches, arrests; boycott on Japanese goods; building in brick – not wood; German evacuation back to Germany
From Peitaiho summer resort, incl. re. School tuition; Women's Medical School; Rockefeller School; salaries (missionaries vs medical school doctors); chancellor dismissed; North/South civil war
From Petaiho summer resort, incl. re. American Board Missions meeting; educational meetings; Interchurch Movement; trip to Great Wall
Incl.re. Opening of school; teaching 45 hrs/wk English in Tungchou
Incl. re. Chinese wedding; recall of 1912 revolution event where Manchu women and children escaped into mission for safety
Incl. re. suffering from flu, going to hospital; John Dewey of Columbia visits Peking; Christmas celebration; consideration of moving school to Shantung province near medical school for men

Incl. re. Dr. Arthur Smith visit; Catholic/Protestant relations; living on salary; connections in Peking; Methodist East Asia Conference; China Medical Conference; Provisional Education Assoc.; student "agitations"; Japan takes over Germany's right in Shantung; policy for medical schools discussion.

Incl. re. celebration of school's affiliation with University; missionaries contact with community and knowledge of native conditions; Girl's schools – differences in motivation for attending; flu – how it is treated in China; 2 New Years; celebrations and customs; Gov't Univ. in Peking open to women

Incl. re. celebration of Passion Week; Biology class using lab. at Rockefeller Pre Med. School; coal mine; Buddhist temple' Tungchou – business session, appointing Chinese to places of responsibility; requesting salary raise; scarlet fever; 1st man to fly Rome to Tokyo

Incl. re. Yutaoho, Fenchoufu valley/canyon description; July 4th celebration; typhus; village life; Pye's missionary family life/Watson medical family life; visitors from Japan Sunday School Convention
Incl. re. Car trip Techow to Linching; circus; student conference at Indemnity College; ; Dr. Boynton (and Grace) arrive; meeting of Wen Yu Hui – dinner and lecture on Russion Bolshevism

Incl.from Wa Fo Ssu (temple in Western Hills), and re. water shortage; flooding, mosquitos, flies, dysentery; trains unavailable due to Military; Ginling Univ.; Miss Ting – YMCA Nat'l Sec. (1st for Chinese); student body in transition; tour down Yangtze; Gen. Feng and exploits
Incl. re. Mrs. Packard's tea for Anna; Peking Univ. Medical School attendees; Fung Fu dinner; wedding plans; a daily schedule; shopping
Incl. re. Auto trip to hills; shopping for Chinese art
Incl.re. Chinese New Year; sick with "grippe"; discussion of morals
Incl. re. Wedding plans; return to U.S. via Rangoon; Calcutta; furlough in NY

Incl. re. Visit to Omaha; return to China; Feng Yu Hsiang seizes Chinese president and Emperor's stronghold – they flee; R.R. lines from Shanghai to Peking cut; visit of mother; work as "Sales Department" of Faculty Cross Stitch work
Incl. re. Political unrest and domestic life

Incl. re. Sale of handmade linens; difficulty in maintaining mission and university; John R. Mott speech at hotel; Paul Monroe attending China Board Medical meeting; Teilhard de Chardin speech at Peking Society Of Natural History

scopecontent.p: Correspondence in this subseries is primarily between Anna and Stanley Wilson and their daughters.
